</question from>



<question>



What could Hollywood do to make it's films even better?



Watch me asking this question on video here: http://uk.video.yahoo.com/watch/2666348/...



</question>



<answer from>



Martin
Member since: 06 December 2005
Total points: 1937 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I think the attachment to celebrities is good for business but bad for the art form - why do all the stories ever thought up need to be acted out by the same 20 actors?



Also, Hollywood should give its audience more credit: perhaps people want more interesting and less formulaic films on the scale that only Hollywood can provide. Just think about the great work done in the 1970s with challenging and relevant films like Apocalypse Now.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thanks!

Kurtis Stryker

</answer from>



<answer>



Hi Greg.



I haven't read all of the other comments yet and like them I'm not sure if mine will ever make a difference as I feel that this is all for show so that the moguls will simply want to be seen to be doing something about the slog that's being created over the last few decades (assuming this is the reason why you're posting this).



But for what it's worth, it's definitely the problem in terms of the attitude towards the writing talent that obviously no longer exists. What do I mean? All the writing talent that Hollywood once had have all dissipated back to the theaters, journalism, television, literature, etc, etc. These are the places where writers were originally sourced in their craft before making it to Hollywood. But the way in which they have been treated these past few decades is it any wonder why they no longer exist and why CGI is a very poor method of covering up the fact that nothing is being produced any more? You know the "cause-and-effect" score, and it also applies here. What's being produced now are CGI-laden video games masquerading as films; it's really not convincing, terribly lame and obvious that there are no more great and original ideas.



Product placement is also a problem. Every film I watch nowadays (especially typically poor efforts with Will Smith in it) have nothing but a barrage of insulting advertisements being bombarded onto the screen in the most shallow and shameless fashion. I get enough of that on TV. When I go to the cinema all I ask is for art made by a team effort of artists...NOT idiots interested in nothing more than lining their own pockets.



Yes, people are willing to pay to see shallow gimmicky films, but I take it that ticket sales for all types of films recently still must be depleting more and more in recent decades?



I find it funny that it is said that the theater is a writers' medium, the TV a producer's and cinema the director's. I doubt this would be the case if there were no talented writers at all. It starts with them and everything else falls into line. Let's get that back and put some dignity back into Hollywood!



It was a force to be reckoned with......once.



Source(s):



More craft, more common sense, less greed. You know it makes sense.



</answer>

<answer>



I don't think Hollywood benifits in sequals or prequils by assuming the audience will just accept unsubtle changes sometimes unbalancing changes in the story line.



Well in the case of AVP 2 they broke the form of the story we knew from previous alien and preditor films. The script writers added in the new preditor/alien hybrid and it's new way of speedily gesting aliens in a new way, but yet the newly gestated aliens still looked like the older aliens.



I am a fan of the alien hopping out of the pod gestating thing. Preditor/alien oozing new alien into victim did not seem to make much sense having seen the aliens that pop of of the pods then attach to victims face taking hours or days to gestate in host.



Other then that Hollywood needs more adult action adventure or sci-fi 3-D movies.



</answer>

<answer>



Films these days just seem to have no imagination and often if imagination has been Incorporated into a film it seems too far fetched. No one hardly ever gets the balance right. I think Hollywood directors need to look more at what films used to be like, what made them so successful and why people would get excited over them.



Not only that i think there are too many films, there should be a limit of how many movies are released in a year. People would appreciate a good movie more if there weren't so many. What happened to the days when people would get excited about a new film being released, it hardly ever happens anymore.
It would also be nice if films weren't just based on America, and the story's involved real people with real personalities and story's that weren't too far fetched but still offered escapism. Don't get me wrong, some films get this right but it is becoming rare.



</answer>

<answer>



To make films better,



1. Hollywood needs to stop trying to remake old classics, especially old British classics, they just don't work.



2. Continuity is a must in all films and programmes, and there's nothing worse seeing a scene from various angles with objects dissapearing and appearing all the time.



3. No matter how fictional a film is it should have some element of realism about it, otherwise it just turns into a complete joke and loses all credibility. A recent super hero film is a prime example, how can a bad guy learn to use something that he never developed, quicker than the good guy who designed it, this just spoils the whole film.



4. Horror films are too predictable these days too, with the shock factor concentrating more on special effects, rather than the good old format of scare the hell out of you and you just don't see it coming.
5. Also Hollywood should stop trying to re write history, all i'll say is U571



</answer>

<answer>



It seems that today Hollywood is relying too much on the work of others. Such as the adaptation of comic books or video games and such. There are many writers and producers that have great ideas for films but many are cast aside for the work of others.



It also seems unfair to many actors and actresses that are cast for parts that are taken by the same 20 actors as I think Martin D pointed out. There are several directors and also actors/actresses that could do the job probably a lot better than some of the big players.



Hollywood studies are not willing to take a calculated risk to dip their toes into the water of the unknown, safety to them it seems is their secret to success. I'm sure that many people would say that safety is whats bringing them all the money and this is a valid point. Although it wouldn't hurt them to take a risk every now and again. With the money that they are raking in every year I'm sure a few hundred bucks won't be missed.



To conclude, there were many films back in the 1960's that were "risque" that did very well at the box office. Hollywood may have to go backwards to go forwards in this instance. Sorry I've written an essay!



</answer>

<answer>



I love film, even bad film. Films that are generally considered to be bad can have a certain fascination and provide a perverse satisfaction for the viewer. It is the mediocre, bland directionless and formulaic crap that irritates and angers me. There are excellent films coming out of studios all the time. Watch ‘The Assignation of Jessie James by the Coward Robert Ford’ as an example of intelligent quality. It’s not that you need to do it better, if everything was great we’d have no bench marks against which to measure. In the words of Billyboy Shakespeare ‘If all the world was palying holidays, to sport would be as tedious as to work, but when they seldom come they whished for come and nothing pleaseth like rare accidents’. I’ve even met someone who thought ‘Pearl Harbour’ was great … there’s no accounting for taste. What I would say however, is that when Hollywood makes films in an historical context a responsibility to the past should be acknowledged.



</answer>

<answer>



Stop being so incestious,  why is it the same few writers regurgitate the same tripe over and over.  Hollywood and even the UK film industry is now more concerned with whether they can also have a computer game and sountrack cd to go with the film.



It should all be about the story, most productions nowadays are cut down to the basics, most producers would say honed. I would say fabricated.  Take even friends as an example.  Every line is fabricated to feed the next character.  Some are funny but it is certainly corntrived and not very real.



I wrote a screenplay and have sent it to a lot of people and they all loved it, they asked me to rewrite it and submit it but eveyone gave me conflicting points of view, so how can I rewite it to what they expect?  The way the industry showld work is that the producers get a good original story which may be a bit rough and work with the writer to produce a great film.  It may take a little longer but you will certainly start to see some nice original work comming through.



</answer>

<answer>



In order to make for Hollywood to make films better they should invest in writers from around the globe. The current crop of regurgitation's of formulaic films have rendered Hollywood un-original and thus un-inspiring. The commercial endeavours of studios is the main problem as it's a lot easier to finance and make profits from say Spiderman 4 then it is to gamble on a unknown director making a risky film albeit possibly innovative. When David Fincher made 'Seven' i thought the mould had been broken and we would see more films of that calibre. Yes we have had films with a 'Sixth Sense' style twist more frequently but films which connect with an audience, in an inspiring way are few and far between. You could say the audience is partly to blame because when a filmmaker does play with the form and conventions of film. IE. Tarantino 'Planet Terror', they fail to become commercial hits, which Hollywood as a business cannot tolerate. Maybe each studio should be forced to make only one picture above $100 million and have to invest in 10 smaller 10 million dollar productions per year only. That way some degree of originality might filter through past Indiana Jones 4, Batman 6, Saw 4 etc.



</answer>

<answer>



Be more original for a start.  Alien was a brilliant film, as was Predator, but alien Vs Predator?  Not exactly original really.  There are far too many films based on comic books too.  Whilst Superman, Batman, Spider-man and the x-men are good films that are obviously successful, it seems that all Hollywood can do now-a-days is scrape the comic book barrel.



Also, spend less money above the line.  I think that spending all the budget on special effects and big name stars insults the intelligence of the cinema viewing public.  People need to be emotionally attached to a character, This is done through good, intelligent scripts, not through explosions and a famous face.  Some of the best films that you see where made on extremely low budgets, and I think this is the main thing that spoils Hollywood movies.



Another thing with Hollywood is that you always see the same names all the time.  I would love to see more emerging talent coming through, be it actors, writers, directors or whoever.



So to summarise, for Hollywood to start making good films again, they need to Spend less money on better, fresh, original scripts that are character driven and do not insult the intelligence of the viewer.



</answer>

<answer>



Improve on its Script writing; some new fresh scriptwriters would make all the difference!



After all European and British films always have better scripts, where lack of Imagination on Hollywood's part tends to do allot of remakes of very good foreign film genres or classic old Hollywood styles.



This is where more damage to the original version is done, with the amount of changes in the script, this can crucify the film!



Simply to up box office takings with over hyped trailers, or marketing a 5-10 rated Star in the lead, so they can draw in the crowds is not going to make it a good movie!!



Hollywood Studios simply cannot come up with decent scripts of their own, their either totally pointless in plot, or lack substance in lead characters, unbelievable due to B' rating acting from pretty actor/actresses, who lets 'face' it only have their looks to go on!



Also very bad endings, short or unrealistic can really mess a film up...



Why you wanted to go down the road of the overdone and worn out Alien/Predator series is beyond me, its been played to death, sorry. (Though I have to say it was amusing!)
More innovative Sci-Fi and Fantasy films should be looked into. A friend and myself have been working on such a script as it goes, with a very Gothic Dark edge, a more in-depth realism, with a very cool storyboard. After all it has to appeal to a more Adult age rating rather than PG. Otherwise it just loses any momentous appeal to an audience.



Hollywood needs to stop and think about hyped up over done action and get some feeling back into its Creative ideas, otherwise they all end up being the same, boring and predictable...



</answer>

<answer>



1)Concentrate on using actors and not just star actors. Some of these stars are pleasing on the eye but not character actors at all
2) Stop using English actors with posh voices as the baddies - it gets a bit boring, try having Americans as baddies for once.
3) Stop having the story line where the baddie killed the goodies family 3 years earlier and they just happened to bump into each other.
4) Too much emphasis on special effects. I dislike the over the top action and near missis.
5) History is facinating, if making an historical film, stick to the facts (where possible).
6) Some films are great for the American markets, but there is a whole world outside of America and some American films are too self praising, too "God bless America". It does not sit easy with non Americans
7) Improve the scripts - some are so cringe worthy and embarrasssing
8) Why remake classic films like The Italian Job? It (the remake) was shocking!!!!



thanks for asking the question. Hollywood does make some good films and he given millions of people great joy.

aceofspi...
Member since: 08 October 2006
Total points: 121 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I don't think Hollywood CAN make it's films better.  That's not a positive or negative statement, I think it's just the way it is.  Hollywood is not about art it's about money.  In order to survive it needs to keep pushing the envelope (not the CGI envelope, mind) and attempt to tell entertaining stories that do the job - take people out of their lives for 90 minutes.  If anything, it needs to work on its stories/scripts - then even the most generic of potboilers can at least deliver some goods.



Hollywood needs to encourage and accept new talent from across the world and set up a system that allows writers to be able to access the sytem directly (a simple script reading service for studios that allows people to send in ideas, stories, screenplays etc).  The BBC does this - to an extent - with the BBC writer's room and there are other services available out there.  Not everybody with talent has an agent (and not everybody with an agent has talent) so there needs to be a simple honesty between author and studio - an acceptance of first time screenwriters and also the knowledge that any submissions can be bought and altered accordingly.  I think there's a definite way of allowing a bridge to be built between Hollywood and its consumers as there feels to be a vast divide.  Open the lines of communication.  That might help.



</answer>



<answer from>

<answer>



Pay more attention to the writers and less to the art designers who constantly screm for more and more expensive and ultimately pointless CGI. Hollywood in the last 15-20 years or so seems to have suffered from a lack of substance in its films, and is producing more and more mind-numbing teen-something films and really bad remakes.



Whats needed is directors and influential producers to have the bottle to stand up to this growing infatuation with inane recycled jokes and hollow characters, and to actually start making films which have something to them. There are plenty of books to choose from, and while I do critisize films based on books for the bad interpretation, if they were handled properly and with a little respect, they could work. The Lord of the Rings showed that this really is the case.



</answer>

<answer>



Whenever religion is involved, why not let the guy downstairs win once in a while. Who's to say that just because "Good" triumphs over "Evil" that it makes the world a better place? The leaders of the world tend to rely on their affiliation to God and use religion to support their message to the people yet we still live in a war-ravaged world. Good and evil are a matter of opinion and I'm sure that the majority of the film-going are intelligent enough to know what's right and what's wrong.



I know it's been said before but the use of CGI for sake of it is becoming tedious beyond compare. It'd be nice for directors to revert to techniques using miniatures, matte paintings and actual set building again.



As an aside, please can there be a reduction in the number of video game tie-ins of films these days? More often than not they're rushed to coincide with the films release and the end product is pretty poor. There are far too many mention but was there really any need for the Golden Compass and Spiderwick Chronicles games??



</answer>

<answer>



I think in order to amplify their horizons, Hollywood could do more co-productive work with production companies in other countries, therefore offering their undoubtedly superior technical expertise and budget capacity to people who might have great ideas for fresh scripts, plots and other creative aspects, and as many have said divert from the formula which makes Hollywood so predictable and identifieble, but keep the quality of the production. They could ask these foreign companies to hold festivals and such to get people to introduce script or just ideas which can then be developed.
By producing films in foreign countries you are also giving the people there a chance to learn new techniques in production etc, give them more work, unknown actors an opportunity to shine. Just look at what the kids on the brazilian pproduction "City of God" did. Good script, good acting, good camera technique and sound, good directing, great film! Hollywood could help develop more productions  while respectic the local flavour and elements that make the movies special.



An example of a film I did NOT like, but think would have been so much better if it had been done with local talent instead of Hollywood, was The House of Spirits (based on the book by Isabel Allende).  So yeah, co-produce with other countries, using their talents.



</answer>

<answer>



Make films that relate more to your viewers deep emotional questions. Use these films to provide them with secret answers that they cannot or will not relate ordinarily with others.
By way of illustration, I'd like to use the example of going to church on Sunday. You go to church not knowing what to expect but, you as well as others have deep questions that need answers. You get to church and, during the course of the service you see and hear information that not only gives you answers but it also changes your life positively.
It doesn't end there, you discover amazingly that after church you are not the only one. Other folks get answers and are changed as well.
It's a win-win situation for both you (producers) and the viewers of the film



Source(s):



Just plain thinking



</answer>

<answer>



The question says it all.  Hollywood starts from the position of thinking that it's already great - it's not.  Often it's appalling, most times it's mediocre, sometimes it's inspiring. Rarely is it brilliant.



To improve:
Replace CGI with plot & character development.
No more comic-book adaptations - they're all crap
When adapting a book - stick to the book
No more sequels / prequels
Don't 'try to be historically accurate' just be historically accurate
And learn basic rules of grammar, it is its not it's



</answer>

<answer>



I believe the days of the Hollywood blockbuster movie are long gone.  People are fed up with over the top special effects, remakes, dumbed down story lines and the same, very small, pool of actors that crop up all the time.



Also, Hollywood is up against the improved standard of TV shows, they are getting better all the time in terms of overall quality while the blockbuster films of the week are just drab, dull, recycled stories, same actors, and a real insult to adult viewers.



So to answer, I would say, divide the budget, share it, make more films/movies, use new talent, don't be afraid to make movies that will appeal to grown up adults, no more remakes or sequel/prequels and take a risk on original story lines.



PS, leave costume drama to us Brits, we do them so much better :)



</answer>

<answer>



i think things need to be scaled back somewhat. if you look at the very first alien film, it is fantastic and regularly makes top 100 lists but would it ever be made like that today? i think it's unlikely. that's a great shame



the industry also needs less reliance on celebrity. i find it confusing why even an animated feature cannot be made without celebrity voices. most actors are where they are today because of their looks, and there are far better voice actors around so why do animated characters need celebrity voice overs?



personally i was hoping the writers strike would lead to an actors strike as well. i think thats what the industry needs in order to get rid of the old and bring in a new more independent system and way of thinking



for a quick fix, Hollywood might certainly look toward more originality as it's extremely hard to find. this year from the top of my head we have Indiana Jones 4 and a remake of the Adromeda Strain



</answer>

<answer>



I studied film for near enough 5 years through both College and University. I think that Hollywood is constantly adapting to public perceptions and fears. For example, post Vietnam you had a hole spate of War films, Born on the fourth of July, Platoon, Casualties of War, The dear hunter etc. These were popular in the 80s and early 90's and were reactionary after the event had took place because directors felt the public had to be reminded whilst also tapping into the angst felt by the men returning. Spielberg made Munich not just because people needed to know about the events but because the public needed to be reminded about the political turmoil it caused within the country it effected the meaning duplicitous being that you can take one side or the other, in the case of Munich to break it down simply, Arab or Jew, and as a subtext Democrat or Republican.



Popcorn flicks and animations have a thematic message within them i.e. Mulan was a critique of the single child policy in China which meant that girls are being left to die because it was more desirable to have boys. Film makers within Hollywood are under enormous pressures both politically and financially to produce films that go along with public opinion, make money, and in some case don't question the status quo.



So to answer the question Hollywood should be prepared to take more risks on the films it produces. Surprise, shock, make the audience laugh, cry, and especially think. Working within the film industry is a gift and it is surely the case that to make films that don't ask audiences questions of themselves and there society is a waste of that gift. In short Hollywood films could be better if the producers are willing to stick there heads above the parapet in order to challenge there audiences.



</answer>



<answer from>



Jo P
Member since: 15 May 2008
Total points: 104 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Things that I Hollywood could impove films by:



Have 'open audition' for screen writers/scripts'.
I believe that you should stop relying on sequels.
If you are going to make a sequel then it needs to have its own storyline but still be linked with the original in small aspects - I don't want to go watch an exact replica of the first film.
More unknown actors need to be used - don't get me wrong I love the big stars like everyone does but there is more talent out there that could be used.  Also all shapes and sizes of actors should be used - not everyone is a size 0 and 6ft high...  People can relate more to an everyday type of person and believe that it is them in the film.......  It's what makes people get into the film more...
For every couple of 'big' films made then a small one could be funded.  This would allow other scripts to be used and you would probably be suprised at how well it could turn out - as someone said on another answer, think Quentin - he made some great films with not much funding.



But this is only my opinion and am sure it won't count very much.  Though it is nice to be asked.



</answer>



<answer from>



Bigdream...
Member since: 15 September 2006
Total points: 1794 (Level 3)



</answer from>

<answer>



Prisoner Of Azkaban.
It was the first film to start exploring Harry coming to terms with his parents death, and it was when the franchise began to get darker and more mature.
Goblet Of Fire was good, but it all felt a bit rushed.
The maze task was just so rushed, and too many monsters missed out, to be at all scary.
As for Order Of The Phoenix, just how could the longest book be made into the shortest film so far is ridiculous.
It was just a potted version of the book, with little narrative or tension, and obviously we all wanted to see the battle in the ministry, but waht a disappointment.
I hope the rest of them get better, or they're just going to ruin a brilliant opportunity to put those wonderful books on the big screen.



</answer>



<answer from>



SIR 5252005 &gt; Anfield = Home
Member since: 19 September 2007
Total points: 1871 (Level 3)

<answer>



Harry Potter and The Sorcerer's Stone is boring in my opinion.



Harry Potter and The Chamber of Secrets was also a little boring, but it is better than its predecessor, as it is more darker and scarier



Harry Potter and The Prisoner of Azkaban was ok, it is better than the first 2



Harry Potter and The Goblet of Fire is by far the only good one in the series, it is the darkest, scariest and has all the action



Harry Potter and The Order of the Phoenix was too flawed because of that stupid director, just what was he thinking? He cut too many parts from the book, it would have been the best out of the 5 if it had picked the same director that had been picked of Prisoner of Azkaban



So overall I guess it would go in this order-



Goblet of Fire
Prisoner of Azkaban
Order of the Phoenix
Chamber of Secrets
Sorcerer's Stone



</answer>

jenny d
Member since: 27 May 2008
Total points: 1010 (Level 3)



Contributing In:



Painting



</answer from>



<answer>



Prisoner of Azkaban... because had an "artistic touch". I enjoyed the beautiful cinemetography. I liked Cuaron's vision of Hogwarts as bigger, more rambling, more artistic, more Gothic, more intricate, and more surreal. Given the role of time in this story, the huge clock and pendulum were brilliant. This movie was darker, creepier, and more grown-up than the previous (great) movies. Buckbeak is a piece of CGI perfection. But if there is one thing that Cuarón convinces us with this film, it is that this is not a kid's story anymore, even if that was how Chris Columbus played it in the first two movies.



</answer>

<original file>11165.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk21298.txt</current file name>




<category>



Entertainment & Music



Movies



</category>



<question from>



Transit Kirk
Member since: 30 September 2008
Total points: 117 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What was the whole point of Citizen Kane?



</question>



<answer from>



LadyDrea...
Member since: 03 April 2008
Total points: 1661 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



To show the rise and fall of a great man



</answer>



<answer from>



Jay
Member since: 25 January 2007
Total points: 11352 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Satire of Hearst, mostly.



Beyond that, it's a story about how, even when you have it all, what matters most to you are the simplest things (like Rosebud).



</answer>



<answer from>



Evul Bunneh !
Member since: 07 September 2008
Total points: 2447 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



"money cant buy me love" (the beatles)



the point was to show a man through out his life, that seemingly has everything a man could possibly want, yet we see at the end (and first scene) that he has nothing.



- "Rosebud", the name of his slide, that symbolize the time when he was a child, happy, with his family, that was his last word, indicates that all he ever wanted is just to be happy, and all he has done with his life, the money, the fame, the success, all these didn't make him happy, it was when he was a child the last time that he was happy.



great message, and a great film.



</answer>

<original file>11485.html</original file>

<category>

to the song, "You Should Be Dancing" by The BeeGee's and I think they are doing the Charleston or one of those other old time dances? Does anyone recall the name of the movie?



</question>



<additional details>

yes it is stayin alive and not the song that I said but its not in the movie airplane because  think I had already checked that on you tube.

<answer from>



Muse - Viktor's Mommy
Member since: 09 October 2007
Total points: 18023 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



First movie that came to mind was the comedy "Airplane!"  In a flashback scene, the two leading characters are at a bar.  That BeeGees song comes on the jukebox, and they both start dancing (at first with other people and then with eachother).



Edit:  Yeah, I just realized (before coming back on here) that it was indeed "Stayin' Alive".  Now this is going to drive me insane . . .

Thanks.

<answer from>



MANDI L
Member since: 05 November 2007
Total points: 116 (Level 1)

His name is Nigel.  He is not part of the books and was introduced in "Goblet of Fire".  He is in the scene when Ron gets his dress robes.  Nigel delivers them in return for getting Harry's autograph

<question from>



Shoop D
Member since: 30 September 2008
Total points: 50 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Who's the director of "The Office"?



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



Ken Kwapis, a veteran of The Larry Sanders Show and Malcolm in the Middle, directed the pilot[32] and eight other episodes.[11][33][12][34] Daniels, Ken Whittingham,[6], Amy Heckerling,[7] and Bryan Gordon[5] also began directing the show in the first season.



Paul Feig, creator of Freaks and Geeks, directed four second season episodes, and three fourth season episodes. He is currently scheduled to direct another episode. In the third and fourth seasons, directors known for their work on other series and in other media, such as J.J. Abrams, Harold Ramis, Jason Reitman, and Joss Whedon helmed episodes. The fourth season's "Money" marked Lieberstein's directorial debut.



</answer>

<answer>



As R-rated movies, this means that the parents get to make the decision.



The theater should enforce the requirement that underage people be accompanied by a parent/guardian.



I've seen the last 2 Saw movies in theaters (one in the middle of the afternoon and one at night).  Didn't see any children in either show.  Teenagers, yes.



</answer>

<question from>

<question>



What are the james bond movies in order?



</question>



<answer from>



Crystal T
Member since: 06 August 2008
Total points: 1974 (Level 3)



Contributing In:



Movies



</answer from>



<answer>



1. Dr. No (1962)



2. From Russia With Love (1963)



3. Goldfinger (1964)



4. Thunderball (1965)



5. You Only Live Twice (1967)



6. On Her Majesty's Secret Service (1969)



7. Diamonds Are Forever (1971)



8. Live and Let Die (1973)



9. The Man with the Golden Gun (1974)



10. The Spy Who Loved Me (1977)



11. Moonraker (1979)



12. For Your Eyes Only (1981)



13. Octopussy (1983)



14. A View to a Kill (1985)



15. The Living Daylights (1987)



16. Licence to Kill (1989)



17. GoldenEye (1995)



18. Tomorrow Never Dies (1997)



19. The World is Not Enough (1999)



20. Die Another Day (2002)



21. Casino Royale (2006)



22. Quantum of Solace (2008)



Source(s):



http://www.klast.net/bond/filmlist.html



</answer>



<answer from>



Jewels
Member since: 24 September 2008
Total points: 254 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Official James Bond films
Dr. No (1962)



From Russia With Love (1963)



Goldfinger (1964)



Thunderball (1965)



You Only Live Twice (1967)



On Her Majesty's Secret Service (1969)



Diamonds Are Forever (1971)



Live and Let Die (1973)



The Man with the Golden Gun (1974)



The Spy Who Loved Me (1977)



Moonraker (1979)



For Your Eyes Only (1981)



Octopussy (1983)



A View to a Kill (1985)



The Living Daylights (1987)



Licence to Kill (1989)



GoldenEye (1995)



Tomorrow Never Dies (1997)



The World is Not Enough (1999)



Die Another Day (2002)



Casino Royale (2006)



Quantum of Solace (2008)



Other films
Casino Royale (1954 TV program) starring Barry Nelson



Casino Royale (1967), starring David Niven and Peter Sellers



Never Say Never Again (1983), starring Sean Connery



Goldeneye (1989) & Spymaker (1990), films about the life of Bond creator, British author Ian Fleming



Source(s):



http://www.klast.net/bond/filmlist.html



</answer>



<answer from>



Josh C
Member since: 12 June 2008
Total points: 585 (Level 2)



</answer from>

From Russia With Love (1963) sean connery
Goldfinger (1964) sean connery

On Her Majesty's Secret Service (1969) george lazenby
Diamonds Are Forever (1971) sean connery
Live and Let Die (1973) roger moore
The Man with the Golden Gun (1974) roger moore
The Spy Who Loved Me (1977) roger moore
Moonraker (1979) roger moore
For Your Eyes Only (1981) roger moore
Octopussy (1983) roger moore
A View to a Kill (1985) roger moore
The Living Daylights (1987) timothy dalton
Licence to Kill (1989) timothy dalton
GoldenEye (1995) pierce brosnan
Tomorrow Never Dies (1997) pierce brosnan
The World is Not Enough (1999) pierce brosnan
Die Another Day (2002) pierce brosnan
Casino Royale (2006) daniel craig

<original file>13349.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk23724.txt</current file name>




<category>



Entertainment & Music



Movies



</category>



<question from>



Don Rickles & Penn Badgley
Member since: 22 July 2008
Total points: 97 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



How old were Adriana Caselotti and Rory Emerald when they appeared in the (1939 film) The Wizard of Oz?



</question>



<answer from>



Jim T
Member since: 25 October 2006
Total points: 7180 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Strictly speaking, neither 'appeared' in the movie.  Caselotti was 23 when her voice was used.  Emerald was not born until 1948.  His uncle, Roy was an extra and stand in for Ray Bolger at the age of 19.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thank you for a terrific answer.



</asker's comment>

<original file>282.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk25662.txt</current file name>




<category>



Entertainment & Music



Movies



</category>



<question from>



Sarah C
Member since: 04 May 2008
Total points: 88 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Can you give me a detailed plot summary of 'La misma luna' or Under the Same Moon?



Please don't just tell me that the mother and son are apart and try to find each other... I want more of the details into the movie. But again, it doesn't have too detailed to the point of she is wearing what at what time.



</question>



<answer from>



avien
Member since: 24 October 2007
Total points: 476 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



UNDER THE SAME MOON (LA MISMA LUNA) tells the parallel stories of nine-year-old Carlitos and his mother, Rosario. In the hopes of providing a better life for her son, Rosario works illegally in the U.S. while her mother cares for Carlitos back in Mexico. Unexpected circumstances drive both Rosario and Carlitos to embark on their own journeys in a desperate attempt to reunite. Along the way, mother and son face challenges and obstacles but never lose hope that they will one day be together again.



</answer>



<answer from>



sadie
Member since: 14 February 2008
Total points: 400 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



o man...
is this your spanish homework???
:)



</answer>

<question>

<answer from>



Ace 71
Member since: 01 October 2008
Total points: 109 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Of course it's okay.  For the most part these are mainstream movies, financed by big business.  As long as you are able to distinguish between fantasy and reality you are fine.



</answer>



<answer from>



manly_ma...
Member since: 05 September 2006
Total points: 347 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Everyone enjoys being frightened or disgusted one in a while, and watching horror movies at night is how they should be watched...daytime watching is like sacrilege. So, it's fine, as long as you don't start getting turned on by the violence.



</answer>



<answer from>



cri
Member since: 01 October 2008
Total points: 98 (Level 1)

<answer>



Remote (1993)
starring  Chris Carrara, Jessica Bowman, John Diehl, Tony Longo, Stuart Fratkin
IMDb synopsis:
"Home Alone" clone about a 13-year-old boy who is obsessed with making remote-controlled toys. He decides to put them to use when he's trapped in a vacant model suburban house with three moronic prison escapees; he proceeds to make mincemeat out of them.



Yahoo! synopsis:
Randy, a 13-year-old boy, designs high-tech remote-controlled toys that are capable of performing amazing tricks. When one of his gadgets wipes out a friend's science project, his parents attempt to separate the boy from his toys, and soon everything spins out of control.



I found one place where it's available but fairly expensive, perhaps because it's obscure:
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00004R...

http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0107944/
http://shopping.yahoo.com/p:Remote:18001...

<answer>



Spider Man 3 - Budget of $258m
Avatar - $250m
Quantum of Solace - $230m
King Kong - $207m
The Golden Compass - $205m
Superman Returns - $204m
Spiderman 2 - $200m
Prince Caspian - $200m
Titanic - $200m
Iron Man - $186m
Terminator 4 - $185m
Indiana Jones 4 - $186m
The Dark Knight - $185m
Narnia: Lion Witch n Wardrobe- - $180m
Rush Hour 3 - $180m
WALL-E - $180m
Evan Almighty - $175m
Wild Wild West - $175m
Waterworld - $175m
The Mummy - Tomb of the dragon emperor - $175m



Hope thats enough :)



It may surprise you that Jurassic Park with a budget of $63m doesn't actually feature anywhere near the top. However with it's huge box office revenues, it remains one of the most profitable films of all time.



Si



</answer>

<question from>



superman...
Member since: 24 January 2008
Total points: 1814 (Level 3)



</question from>



<question>



If you have seen citizen kane, hwat do you think he meant by rosebud ?



does it symbolise the chair being his only companion not leaving him while his close friends and loved ones left him. what do you think?



</question>



<answer from>



Bogwoppi...
Member since: 26 April 2006
Total points: 34278 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



He was talking about his childhood toy a simple sledge. Symbolising the simple life he could have had if he had stayed with his family, instaed of the life of priviledge and fame.



</answer>



<answer from>



Tigger
Member since: 20 June 2006
Total points: 35970 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



Take a look at what's being burned in one of the last scenes of the movie, then think of what Kane was shouting as he was playing as a boy.



</answer>



<answer from>



LilyRT
Member since: 25 September 2006
Total points: 5364 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



He was thinking of the last time he was happy.  Back when he didn't have any money but was still with his family enjoying sledding.  The things that brought him the most joy couldn't be had for money.  A cliched sentiment now, but an unexpected message at the end of the great depression and powerfully delivered.



</answer>

<question>



DVD Release Dates of Hollywood Movies ?



Where can i find the DVD release date of new and upcoming Hollywod Movies ??
and also the release date of their Blu Ray Versions ?



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



I was looking for this kind of info recently and just googled the titles.



Another source might be IMDB,



If you have a movie through the mail membership you can enter the title or find it in the database and add it to your queu. If you are with Blockbuster, is sits below your list waiting until it is realeased. Then it is automatically added to your list of movies that will come to you in the mail.



Source(s):



www.imdb.com



</answer>

Penguin in "Batman Returns"

<answer from>



Ray B
Member since: 21 March 2008
Total points: 244 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Batman (1966) The Joker, Catwoman, The Riddler, The Penguin



Batman (1989) The Joker



Batman Returns (1992) Catwoman, The Penguin



Batman: Mask of the Phantasm (1993) The Joker, The Phantasm



Batman Forever (1995) The Riddler, Two-Face



Batman and Robin (1997) Poision Ivy, Mr. Freeze



Batman Begins (2005) Ra Ahs Ghoul, The Scarecrow



The Dark Knight (2008) The Joker



There are two movie serials from the 40's but the villians in those are not from the comic books and were made up just for the use of the serials.



</answer>



<answer from>
Member since: 21 April 2008
Total points: 19076 (Level 6)



</answer from>

Batman 1989 starring Michael Keaton as Batman, Danny Devito as the Penguin and Jack Nicholson as the Joker. Kim Basinger is the girl.

<question from>

</question from>



<question>



In the Terminator films, why are the terminators sent back through time naked?



The question's pretty self-explanatory but why are the terminators (and even Reese) sent back through time without any clothes on?



</question>



<answer from>



Sis F
Member since: 01 December 2007
Total points: 10341 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Movies



</answer from>



<answer>



nothing material can come thru.  thats why they cant bring clothes or weapons.  :)



</answer>



<answer from>



Agent Smith
Member since: 12 August 2008
Total points: 1219 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Because  they use the clothes from the time period they were sent back to. You are not going to be wearing leather in 1776.



</answer>



<answer from>



shobijin
Member since: 31 March 2007
Total points: 253 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Only living organic matter can travel back through time. Anything exposed on the outside has to be organic and it has to be alive. That's why the Terminators are covered in grown organic skin.



Source(s):



I watch the movies and the new series :-)



</answer>



<answer from>



Stephen K
Member since: 18 February 2007
Total points: 445124 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Movies



Comics & Animation



Yahoo! Answers



</answer from>



<answer>



It is mentioned int he first film, but only living matter can come through, so no clothng or guns



</answer>

<answer from>



Marilyn B
Member since: 09 October 2006
Total points: 44629 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Movies



</answer from>



<answer>



If you're looking for one with wolves, then I recommend an old one with Charles Martin Smith called Never Cry Wolf (1983). This film dramatizes the true story of Farley Mowat, when he was sent to the Canadian tundra area to collect evidence of the grievous harm the wolf population was allegedly doing to the caribou herds. In his struggle to survive in that difficult environment he studies the wolves, and realizes that the old beliefs about wolves and their supposed threat are almost totally false. Furthermore, he learns that humans represent a far greater threat to the land, and also to the wolves, a species which plays an important role in the ecosystem of the north.
P.S.--Wolf Creek is a bloody horror film about stranded backpackers in remote Australia who fall prey to a murderous bushman who offers to fix their car, then takes them captive. The title is deceiving.



Source(s):



http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0086005/



</answer>



<answer from>



lulusmil...
Member since: 22 August 2006
Total points: 4215 (Level 4)

<category>



Entertainment & Music



Movies



</category>



<question from>



testpoke...
Member since: 15 September 2008
Total points: 103 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Why Wall-E is very expensive film?



There are no famous acrors, not much of disasters on cars, and buildings.
It is just a CG, expensive things that was made like ships for example what Titanic did, WHy?



</question>



<answer from>



Vincent P
Member since: 11 May 2008
Total points: 424 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



probally because the digital picture and that stuff.



</answer>



<answer from>



Tivogal
Member since: 18 September 2006
Total points: 9304 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Cruise Travel



</answer from>



<answer>



the technical aspects of filming, going over budget.



have a nice day.



</answer>



<answer from>



Becky M
Member since: 08 April 2008
Total points: 1847 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



There are famous actors that do voices in it.
The way it's made is a very long and expensive process - its not like someone just drew it on a bit of paper.



</answer>



<answer from>



puppetsi...
Member since: 01 February 2008
Total points: 1515 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Have you bought a computer recently? They cost a lot don't they. Well, Pixar does all their animation on computer. To do this, they have hundreds of people working on computers all day every day - that means they need lots of computers, lots of computer programs, make backups, use the internet and email, cover other overheads (like heating, building rental, electricity, etc etc)... oh, and they need to hire specialist programmers to make and design all the programs they use to create the animations. That doesn't include all the people they have to pay to do the animations themselves, or the other staff they need to hire, like script writers, marketeers, etc. Nor does it include expensive recording studio time or pay for voice actors (who may have to do more than one take to get it right). There's also usually a bunch of sculptors and artists who work on designs before they commit to the final character designs.



Though they don't have crashing cars, they spend about as much money as any other blockbuster production house. It's just they don't spend it in the same way.



</answer>



<answer from>



dougieb1...
Member since: 30 June 2008
Total points: 2217 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Computer animation is very expensive as there can be anything up to 700 people working on the film for up to 4 years at a time.
Pixar excel in computer animation, and the technology they use is not cheap.



</answer>

<question from>



Caramel Sundae
Member since: 28 November 2007

Contributing In:



Other - Cultures & Groups



</question from>



<question>



In the Sex and The City Movie, what did Miranda say to Carrie? What was the horrible secret?



I was doing something and didn't catch that part but looked like it was something horrifying. I heard Miranda say, "It was only one time.."



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



Miranda unwittingly lets her own unhappiness--created when Steve admits to cheating on her just once--spoil Carrie's. Miranda tells Big that marriage is no good, essentially, and this fact may have contributed to him having cold feet.



</answer>

<answer>



The Descent - Horror film in which a group of women go pot-holing in the Appalachian Mountains. One of the best horror films I've seen in years!



Slither - Horror/Comedy - Alien slug like creatures begin to possess residents of a small town in America. Very funny black humour.



The Host - One of the best Korean horror films - A huge creature erupts from the river in downtown Seoul (Capital of Korea) and kidnaps a schoolgirl. It's up to her family, including her champion crossbow shooting sister, to save her!



</answer>

<answer from>



saristin
Member since: 30 November 2007
Total points: 3035 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Well yes and no.
Yes because if you liked the series it's just great to "have them back" for a while and see what happened/is happening to them. Also as always the locations are beautiful, the fashion the usual (hideous to lovely) and it did not seem as long as it was.
however, having seen it again since, I must say I was quite disappointed. There did not seem to be that much effort put into the storylines (after all, they could have showed pretty much anything, many ladies -me included- would have run to the cinemas anyway).
The storylines are a bit lame, and while I like that Hudson woman who plays Carries assistant, she seems like a pointless filler to an already loooong film (especially as she never even meets "the girls" once).



I enjoyed it the first time round, but watching it again with my boyfriend who tolerated the series, I had to apologize several times for making him watch it.



If you like SATC, you'll like the film. If you don't really care, don't bother. Play spider solitaire for three hours instead, it's more satisfying!



</answer>



<answer from>



Katrin.....
Member since: 11 July 2008
Total points: 772 (Level 2)

<answer>



What do you even like?



Your name inspired the following suggestion:



"La vita e bella". It's an Italian movie about WWII. Don't worry though, it's not a Saving private Ryan movie.



To quote:
"In 1930s Italy, a carefree Jewish book keeper named Guido starts a fairy tale life by courting and marrying a lovely woman from a nearby city. Guido and his wife have a son and live happily together until the occupation of Italy by German forces. In an attempt to hold his family together and help his son survive the horrors of a Jewish Concentration Camp, Guido imagines that the Holocaust is a game and that the grand prize for winning is a tank. "



IMDB:
http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0118799/
Ranks #84 of the 250 best movies in IMDB, event though it's quite unknown.



Recommended!



</answer>

<answer>



Garden State is beautiful, sad and romantic. I have yet to watch it without crying! Its truly amazing and a very unique movie. There is no other like it!

<question from>



Nick Jonas

</question from>



<question>



Rudy and Forrest Gump!!?



1) Why is the quote "Mama always said..." important for development of plot? How does this phrase relate to your own personal growth and development?



2) How do the movies "Rudy" and "Forrest Gump" show that some people have to live life in a box but it is possible to break it and go out of bounds?



3) How are Goals different from Dreams? How do goals and dreams effect one's shape of life?



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



what kind of class are you cheating at here?



It's one thing to ask for help with homework, but these questions are something that should be answered by you personally.



</answer>

<question from>

<question>

You know that song that they always play in old western movies, usually when the bad guy is walking into town, or when they have one of those gun fights in the street? It goes something like "waah-waah-waah ba da-da waah-waah waaaah". Sorry, its the best I can come up with. Anyway, what is that called? I'm trying to find a sound clip of it. <question>



What do you call the people that make soundtracks for movies?



that would be a really cool job.

<answer from>



Panama Joe
Member since: 20 July 2007
Total points: 18559 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Movies



</answer from>



<answer>



look at the credits or titles:  they are often called "Recording Artists" or "Sound Recordist" or even "Sound Artist" or "Sound Editor"



</answer>



<answer from>



Turk
Member since: 08 September 2008
Total points: 238 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



It all depends if someone writes the whole thing it is referred to as a score, as with Star Wars it is referred to as simply the London Symphony Orchestra.  If it is a compilation of songs and scores then it is a Sound Editor



</answer>



<answer from>



ginomel a
Member since: 29 September 2008
Total points: 104 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



they are called soundtrack boys!! hehe just joking!! hhhmmm i



</answer>



<answer from>



Biggie Smalls
Member since: 03 July 2008
Total points: 100 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



If you're referring to the score (instrumental/incidental music in the film) then that would be a Composer.



Examples of Film Composers are: Hans Zimmer (Lion King, Pirates of the Caribbean Trilogy), James Horner (Apocalypto, Titanic), Alan Silvestri (Back to the Future Trilogy), Howard Shore (Lord of the Rings Trilogy), etc, etc.



Thought I'd give you a slightly different answer to some of the others here as your question is a little vague and can be interpreted in different ways.



Source(s):



http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Film_score



</answer>

<question>

Before his death, can't he sense that Anakin have the kind of evil in his heart? I mean, c'mon, Qui-Gon is so wise in that kind of Force stuff, he should have able to predict something out of Anakin.



Overall, is Qui-Gon's fault to indirectly partially cause the purge of the Jedi?



</question>



<answer from>



Crystal T
Member since: 06 August 2008
Total points: 1936 (Level 3)



Contributing In:



Movies



</answer from>



<answer>



I think his passion to fulfill the prophecy could have blinded any doubts he might have had about Anakin,so yes indirectly I think he did.



</answer>



<answer from>



rainfall...
Member since: 24 September 2008
Total points: 603 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Well Anakin Skywalker brought balance to the force. So the real question is does Qui-Gon deserve the credit for Anakin's training?



The six films chronicle the life of Anakin Skywalker right through to his death. Despite all the terrible things that occurred while the empire was in control, overall his existence was a positive thing for the star wars world.



</answer>



<answer from>



weirdice...
Member since: 08 May 2008
Total points: 173 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Edit: I agree with the 2nd answerer.



</answer>



<answer from>



Yorgisbo...
Member since: 08 June 2007
Total points: 361 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Fault? Qui-Gon is in no way responsible for the purge. Indeed, if not for him, the empire would never have been overthrown. Palpatine would have found another way to take control of the Republic and Dooku would have remained his apprentice, or perhaps he would have found another. In any case, in the end it was Anakin who overthrew the empire  and restored balance to the Force, fulfilling the prophecy.



</answer>

<question>



What could Hollywood do to make it's films even better?



Watch me asking this question on video here: http://uk.video.yahoo.com/watch/2666348/...

<answer from>



Martin
Member since: 06 December 2005
Total points: 1879 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I think the attachment to celebrities is good for business but bad for the art form - why do all the stories ever thought up need to be acted out by the same 20 actors?

Also, Hollywood should give its audience more credit: perhaps people want more interesting and less formulaic films on the scale that only Hollywood can provide. Just think about the great work done in the 1970s with challenging and relevant films like Apocalypse Now.



</answer>

Thanks!

<answer from>

</answer from>



<answer>



Mexico City wins because we need urban city atmosphere and make sure the zombies can run!!! And FAST!!!!



</answer>



<answer from>



ang_phx
Member since: 02 October 2006
Total points: 1742 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Mexico City would be very interesting because of the historical landmarks you might be able to film at.  Also the potential for plot lines is probably greater with the whole Inca/Aztec/Myan thing.
If you are hiring a professional crew you might have better luck in Vancouver because so many major productions are done there now because it's cheaper & looks so much like America.
Getting quality help in Mexico shouldn't be to hard though.
I think as a viewer of lots of these types of movies I'd like to see Mexico.  Movies aren't just about plot & acting - location plays a large role as well.



</answer>



<answer from>



swflstee...
Member since: 18 December 2007
Total points: 6741 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



I was in the original movie, Night of the Living Dead. We filmed it locally in our hometown just south of Pittsburgh, PA



</answer>

<category>



Entertainment & Music



Movies



</category>



<question from>



anni333
Member since: 07 October 2006
Total points: 457 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



What does evo mean in the cinema



i want to book to see the latest mummy film.  there are two showings in my local cinema but one has (EVO) against the title.  Does anyone know what this means pls



</question>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



Estimated Viewing Occupancy (EVO)
The number of seats that can view television programming at any given time in a commercial establishment. Estimates for standing areas may also be added to this number.The EVO is used to determine commercial rates for certain sports and standard programming.



</answer>

<question>



'Let him have it Chris'  have you seen it



I saw it last night on late TV. I thought it was so well done with brilliant performances from Ecclestone and the kiddie who played Chris Craig. Arguably a case of the worse injustice in living memory.  Derek Bentley was pardoned 50 years later sadly too late for his campaigning sister who died shortly before.  Craig emigrated to NZ after serving 10 years.  Awesome film



</question>



<additional details>



Even if he did say 'let him have it Chris' meaning shoot the police officer, that first shot only wounded him.  It wasnt until 20 minutes later (when Bentley was in custody) that Craig fired the fateful shot that killed PC  Miles.



</additional details>

<answer from>



chrisjed...
Member since: 11 May 2008
Total points: 544 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Remember seeing the film when it first got released on video (remember those big bulky VHS tapes) it sparked a flood of interest into the case from the media at the time Chris Craig came back from abroad  and did loads of interviews.  The big question and people who debate 'miscarraiges' still debate this point when Derek Bentley said the words Let him have it Chris," did he mean pass the police officer the firearm or shoot the police officer as we know its all in the tone of the voice as to the meaning of the phrase that was the main point of the prosecution at the time they maintained he had said it to have the police officer shot thank god the justice system seems to have moved forward not saying its a perfect system we have because there is no such thing as perfect but it is now better than it was, just a pity it took people like Derek Bentley to endure wrong doings by our courts to get were we are today.



</answer>

<answer>

The case against Derek Bentley was a travesty in my personal opinion ! So sad that both Derek Bentley & P.C. Miles should lose their lives !

<answer from>



Palmerpa...
Member since: 19 November 2006
Total points: 14537 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



I watched East of Eden on tv when I was around eleven or so, and have been a fan of Dean ever since (over forty years). I watched Rebel Without a Cause a couple of years later, and my appreciation for his talents increased even more. Although his performance in Giant gets a bit lost in the sprawl of that picture, he was very good in that as well. 
I'm always curious to know whether his style and appeal would have changed through the '60s and 70's, but his death cut that possibility short way too soon.
As it is, even on the basis of just the three films he starred in, he was one of the great ones.



</answer>

<original file>index;_ylt=AsMNYASKEYNJRQMebrUgsQM6CAx01cd.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk40574.txt</current file name>



<category>



Entertainment & Music



Movies



</category>



<question from>



jacqueli...
Member since: 30 March 2006
Total points: 353 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



A Matrix 3 question...



In Matrix 3 there's a part where Neo goes to see the oracle one last time, he asks her a question and she replies you know why I can't answer that, then she points to a wooden sign above the door way and I believe it says, "Catal Nusre" Does any one have any idea what that means and what it means within the movie? Thanks! :)



</question>



<answer from>



bubblyba...
Member since: 27 November 2007
Total points: 1891 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



The plaque reads "temet nosce" and essentially means "know thyself".  Oracle has stated that "no one can see beyond a choice that they don't understand".  You have to know your self to understand your choices and the consequences that will result from that choice.  I always took it as that whenever he sought the oracle for answers she was vague, she couldn't give him all the answers or tell him what to do he had to make the decisions for himself (free will).  For example in the original Matrix the Orale was suppose to confirm he was the one but she didn't (maybe in another life).  Neo had to do that for himself.  He had to decided whether or not to step up.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thank you! that was awesome! :) i am almost done watchint the 3rd one !!!



</asker's comment>

<answer>



Save the Last Dance
The film stars Julia Stiles and Sean Patrick Thomas as a teenage interracial couple in Chicago who work together to help the main character, played by Stiles, train for a dance audition.

Step Up
The film follows the tale of the disadvantaged Tyler Gage (Channing Tatum) and the privileged modern dancer Nora Clark (Jenna Dewan), who find themselves paired up in a showcase that determines both of their futures. Realizing that they only have one chance, they finally work together.



Source(s):



www.wikipedia.org

<answer from>



Captain Caveman
Member since: 16 January 2007
Total points: 21630 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Steamboat Willie was a short animated film by Walt Disney. It was the third Mickey Mouse cartoon and the first to feature the yet un-named Minnie Mouse. It was also the first disney film with synchronized sound. It is often mistakenly referred to as the first synchronized sound cartoon, but it was not.

Max Fleischer invented the "Bouncing Ball" technique for his " Ko-Ko Song Car-Tune" series of animated sing-along shorts. In May 1924, Fleischer added synchronized sound to this series, using the Phonofilm sound-on-film process developed by Lee de Forest. These Song Car-tunes would last until 1927, just a few months before the actual start of the sound era. This was before Walt Disney's Steamboat Willie.

The cartoon was written and directed by Walt Disney and Ub Iwerks. The title is a parody of the Buster Keaton film Steamboat Bill Jr.



Another often mistaken fact given was music for Steamboat Willie was put together by Wilfred Jackson, one of Disney's animators -- not, as sometimes reported, by the legend of animated music, Carl W. Stalling, of Warner Brothers animation fame.

The film is often critisized for mickey's supposed cruel treatment of animals. I really don''t see that as it's really no different than other animated humor of the day.

All in all it's a nice piece of cartoon history. Pass the popcorn dear.

xx



Source(s):



http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0TPbpvP-o...



</answer>



<answer from>



ANDREW M
Member since: 24 September 2007
Total points: 12085 (Level 6)

<question from>



jennasto...
Member since: 24 March 2007

</question from>



<question>



What is the name of this 1970's horror movie?



A guy gets his head smashed in a album/record press. A short white guy with a blonde bowl-cut has wire framed "Harry potter" type glasses.  I think he was a musician in the late 60's-early 70's. There was music in the movie but I'm not certain if there was singing.



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



Phantom of the Paradise (1974)
IMDb synopsis:
This is Brian De Palma's rock opera version of "Phantom of the Opera" with elements of Faust. Record producer Swan (Paul Williams, who wrote the music) steals both the music and the girl~Phoenix (Jessica Harper)~from composer Winslow Leach (William Finley). Disfigured during an accident at the record factory, Leach plans revenge on Swan and his rock palace, The Paradise. Leach signs a contract with Swan to complete a rock opera based on the life of Faust, planning for Phoenix as the star. Doublecrossed by Swan, who hires rock singer Beef (Gerritt Graham in a role said to have inspired Dr. Frank-N-Furter), Leach exacts his vengeance. 
TRIVIA:
According to William Finley, the record press in which his Winslow character was disfigured was a real pressing plant (it was an injection-molding press at an Ideal Toy Co. plant). He was worried about whether the machine would be safe, and the crew assured that it was. The press was fitted with foam pads (which resemble the casting molds in the press), and there were chocks put in the center to stop it from closing completely. Unfortunately, the machine was powerful enough to crush the chocks that it gradually kept closing. It was Finley's speed and timing that saved him from truly being hurt, as he got his head out just in time. Incidentally, his scream in the scene was real.

You can watch it on YouTube!
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0AVB7aahA...



Source(s):



http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0071994/



</answer>

<question from>



Brayden W. Potter

<question>



How Many "Nightmare On Elm Street" Movies Are There?



I want to know how many "Nightmare On Elm Street" movies there are. I've heard there's remakes of some of them. So don't include the remade versions of them.



</question>



<answer from>



jisdaman...
Member since: 06 August 2008
Total points: 311 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



There were actually 7, but if you want to count Freddy vs. Jason, then there would be 8 total.  Here are the movies, the directors, and the producers.



1. A Nightmare on Elm Street Wes Craven Robert Shaye



2. Freddy's Revenge Jack Sholder David Chaskin



3. Dream Warriors Chuck Russell Wes Craven, Frank Darabont, Chuck Russell, Bruce Wagner



4. The Dream Master Renny Harlin Brian Helgeland, Jim Wheat, Ken Wheat Rachel Talalay & Robert Shaye



5. The Dream Child Stephen Hopkins Leslie Bohem Robert Shaye



6. Freddy's Dead Rachel Talalay Michael De Luca Robert Shaye & Aron Warner



7. New Nightmare Wes Craven Robert Shaye



8. Freddy vs. Jason Ronny Yu Damian Shannon & Mark Swift Sean S. Cunningham



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thanks, Mate.



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Girl, Interrupted
Member since: 16 November 2006
Total points: 23727 (Level 6)



</answer from>

Nightmare On Elm Street  Pt. 3  The Dream Wariors
Nightmare On Elm Street  Pt. 4  The Dream Master
Nightmare On Elm Street  Pt. 5  The Dream Child
Freddy's Dead: The Final Nightmare  Pt. 6
New Nightmare Pt. 7



</answer>

<question from>



WhereIsT...
Member since: 25 July 2008

</question from>



<question>



In the movie "Teeth" why are the textbook photos of the female reproductive organ covered with a sticker?



</question>



<additional details>



Answer only if you've seen the movie.



In the high school they were allowed to show the penis and study it, but the teacher said the female reproductive organ needs to be covered.



</additional details>



<answer from>



ShinyThi...
Member since: 04 September 2008
Total points: 510 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Well this probably isn't something that happens in this day and age (but maybe in some parts of the States, I wouldn't know) but I think it was done in this film because it went along with the theme.

I'm sure at some point in history kids were given health books in school where possibly there was something covering the more graphic pictures because over-reactive parents and officials were worried about psychologically damageing their preciouse children. I don't know if ever the covering was only for one gender but it is possible since girls are supposed to be proper and virgin-like and not even think about sex.



But Teeth was based on the  vagina denta myth. "Various cultures have folk tales about women with toothed vaginas, frequently told as cautionary tales warning of the dangers of sex with strange women."

And if you noticed all the guys in that chick's life were dirt bags trying to have sex with her. So I think it was more for the effect of the themes in the film which were about women, gender differences and sex.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Ok thanks. Yeah the movie really freaked me out but it was kinda funny too in a sick way lol. But I just remembered they did have a side diagram of the female organs but the front view was covered because it was too graphic I guess.



</asker's comment>






<original file>index;_ylt=ApDF.6LsYhw0AMbhPbtSM3A6CAx3bb5.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk46135.txt</current file name>



<category>



Entertainment & Music



Movies



</category>



<question from>



Paul M
Member since: 09 September 2008
Total points: 126 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Questions for the movie A Beautiful Mind, best answer +10 points?



Hi, I need help with three questions for this reflection assignment. I just need to get very simple answers/ideas so I can expand on the answers myself, Thank You (Best Answer Guaranteed :D)
1. What role does logic play in John Nash's mind?
2. How is the concept of "mind over matter" portrayed in the movie?
3. How does Nash travel the fine line between genius and insanity?



</question>



<answer from>



Righteous Indignation
Member since: 12 August 2007
Total points: 1129 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



1. Figuratively speaking, logic plays the role of strength and weakness in Nash's mind. It is through logic that he is able to work out complex mathematical equations with relative ease. At the same time, logic turns against him when he believes that he is able to see what does not exist, i.e. government conspiracies evident solely by patterns of letters and words.

2. Mind over matter-- I guess Morpheus said it best in The Matrix. "The mind makes it real." His schtizophrenia allowed his mind to see and experience things that did not exist. His mind overpowered all of his other senses.



3. "Much madness is the divinest sense." I'm not sure if he "traveled" the line perfectly. It would appear that at times he fell off onto each side. I guess you could say that his genius is apparent in his academia as well as his professional success, e.g. the Nobel Prize. His genius, once again, was his weakness. He began to see things that did not exist and used his "genius" to perceive things as real. As illogical as it seemed, his genius was the reason he was "recruited" to work for the government. It takes a genius mind to create a separate consciousness apart from one's own that takes on a different personality and to have conversations with it.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thank You, 
Excellent Answering ;)



</asker's comment>

<original file>index;_ylt=Au0Q5RyBbbB_rfNo1h2X6c2xBwxd6c7.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk48362.txt</current file name>



<category>



Entertainment & Music



Movies



</category>



<question from>



HaPpInEs...
Member since: 05 August 2008
Total points: 3 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



To All Movie Geeks? movies?



Well not Geeks just know it alls!

1) Is a films success measured by; How it does in an individual country OR world wide gross?

2) To the box office people; would mumma mia be doing better or dark knight? mumma mia has made more in the uk, but not in the us nor world wide. so which film has been the most succesful?

3) What would the UK box office people consider more succesfull, world wide gross or there country?



</question>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



1) Any film executive is going to pay attention to worldwide gross, but the average Joe will care if it made money in America.  A lot of faded action stars (Stallone, Van Damme, etc.) were able to keep their careers afloat because their films were popular in foreign countries where the film's appeal was based on stunts and special effects rather than dialogue.

2) "The Dark Knight" would be doing better because of its overwhelming success.  It may become the highest-grossing movie ever.

3) See answer #1.  Those in the movie biz will care about worldwide, whereas the avg. person will gauge a movie's success by how many people they know see it and like it, usually.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



1.Worldwide.
2.The Dark Knight. It has made a dam lot of money.
3.World Wide = ]



</answer>






<original file>index;_ylt=AuHOtuGNACh4pGtvbjbN1rI6CAx0c04.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk48435.txt</current file name>



<category>



Entertainment & Music



Movies



</category>



<question from>



Freckles...
Member since: 17 June 2008

<answer from>



OCNell
